title: 107_hr5091
content: The Act is titled the "Canceling Loans to Allow School Systems to Attract Classroom Teachers Act." It allows for additional qualified loan amounts for student loan forgiveness. The "Canceling Loans to Allow School Systems to Attract Classroom Teachers Act" allows for up to $17,500 in loan repayment for elementary or secondary school teachers meeting specific requirements on a first-come first-served basis. The loan repayment program gives priority to special education teachers supporting children with disabilities corresponding to their training. Teachers eligible for the loan repayment program must have knowledge and teaching skills in the relevant curriculum areas, work in underperforming schools, or teach mathematics or science. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2003 and beyond is provided for direct loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary may repay up to $17,500 from appropriated funds under certain conditions. The Secretary may repay up to $17,500 to elementary or secondary school teachers who meet specific requirements, with priority given to special education teachers supporting children with disabilities. The Secretary may repay up to $17,500 to teachers in public or nonprofit private elementary or secondary schools who are teaching children with disabilities corresponding to their training and have demonstrated knowledge in the curriculum areas they teach. In 1965, teachers who fail to meet annual objectives for 2 years or teach math/science may face consequences. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose until 2003. SEC. 3. CANCELLATION OF STUDENT LOAN INDEBTEDNESS FOR SPOUSES, SURVIVING JOINT DEBTORS, AND PARENTS. Definitions for eligible public servant and eligible victim are provided for individuals who were either killed or permanently disabled as a result of injuries sustained in the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack. The terms "eligible spouse," "eligible surviving debtor," and "eligible parent" are defined in accordance with regulations of the Secretary for individuals affected by the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack. The Secretary of Education will discharge Federal student loan indebtedness for eligible spouses affected by the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack. The consolidation loan indebtedness of eligible spouses, surviving debtors, and parents incurred on behalf of eligible victims can be discharged or canceled by the method used under section 437(a). The Secretary shall establish procedures for discharge or cancellation of Federal student loan indebtedness for eligible spouses, surviving debtors, and parents. Actions will be taken to publicize the availability of such relief. (d) Availability of Funds for Payments.--Funds available for making payments to lenders for the discharge of indebtedness of deceased or disabled individuals can also be used for eligible spouses, surviving debtors, and parents. (e) Applicable to Outstanding Debt.--This section applies only to Federal student loans outstanding on September 11, 2001. SEC. 4. INFORMATION ON BENEFITS TO RURAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS. The Secretary will notify eligible local educational agencies about benefits for teachers in rural schools and encourage agencies to inform their teachers about these benefits.
